author: phabc
content: Has anyone looked into front-running strategies post EIP-1559? Most miners just sort by highest gas price, so it's easy for frontrunners to compete to be the first while in the mempool, but I wonder if it will be the same post EIP-1559. Right now miners probably extract *some* of the revenue from the frontrunning that pay high gas prices, but curious what will happen post EIP-1559

author: phabc
content: I guess that's tightly related to implementation, which probably won't change on that aspect

author: sky.cactus
content: <@278762485497069569> unless miners change their sorting algorithm, front running will be the same.

author: sky.cactus
content: As long as miners decide order, front running will be a bribery game.

author: phabc
content: Yes I understand, but the only reason why they would keep this sorting algorithm is for when blocks would hit the 20M limit, which I guess is a sufficient reason to keep things the same, in case it happens, but still may be faster for them not to do any sorting since most of the time they can just execute all txs in the mempool that have enough basefee + min tip

author: sky.cactus
content: I suspect that the sort itself is dirt cheap compared to most of the work miners do.

author: phabc
content: Most likely indeed

author: sky.cactus
content:
It seems like unnecessary added complexity to have something like:
```ts
if (transactions.filter(eligible).sum(tx => tx.gas) > block.gasLimit * 2) {
    transactions.sort()
}
```instead of just
```ts
transactions.sort()
```

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, it *would* be cool to break front runners so I would support mining nodes adding that in just to screw with them.  ðŸ˜€

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, I suspect you'll end up with front running becoming a game of hashing power then, unless miners store transactions in a FIFO array.

author: sky.cactus
content: Actually, I think miners would prefer a client that actively supports front-running, since that can be a money maker.

author: afdudley
content: Miners already provide this service.

author: sky.cactus
content: Which service?

author: afdudley
content: they already support side channel payment for block inclusion.

author: sky.cactus
content: How does one contact a miner in order to get special inclusion?

author: sky.cactus
content: I haven't seen it advertised anywhere, and this doesn't feel like a feature that would need to be kept undergound.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the fear of "miners will collude to drive base-fee to 0 so they can force first price auction" could be addressed by increasing the elasticity from 2x to say 4x or 5x or whatever we think clients can reasonably handle.  Average gas used per second would remain at 10M on average, but we would allow bigger bursts.

author: sky.cactus
content: I personally am not worried about that type of collusion, but I also think that increasing elasticity is generally a positive thing up until we reach the threshold where client software starts choking due to single-block-size.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm guessing that at the moment we have no idea at what threshold clients start choking on blocks?

author: afdudley
content:
> How does one contact a miner in order to get special inclusion?
<@!301186049323958275> I just asked one in person. someone else earlier today related a similar story to me, so I'm pretty sure it's just based on personal relationships and probably very expensive.

author: sky.cactus
content: How does one create those personal relationships?  Asking for a friend.  ðŸ˜¬

author: afdudley
content: It's short list of players that can do that... exchanges, whales, people providing hash power to pools, etc etc.

author: afdudley
content: OTC desks.

author: sky.cactus
content: It feels like a service they could just advertise.

author: afdudley
content: it's 6 people who need to talk to 6 other people why would they advertise?

author: sky.cactus
content: You could even formalize it by letting people buy execution time on the miner directly where you are given a proposed block in and you can spit out a new block and you are charged for execution time and any difference in gas fees.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think there is a market, especially in the arbitrage and front running crowd, for on-miner execution opportunity.

author: afdudley
content: you should find some pool operators and talk to them.

author: afdudley
content: There is no reason to advertise...

author: sky.cactus
content: Advertising gets access to more customers.

author: afdudley
content: If someone has built such a tool they have 1 to 3 customers and that's it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think it is more than that.

author: afdudley
content: They don't need anymore...

author: afdudley
content: The market is tiny tiny tiny.

author: sky.cactus
content: I *personally* know at least 3 people who would pay for on-miner execution opportunity.

author: sky.cactus
content: Perhaps I just "know everyone in the space" and don't realize it?

author: afdudley
content: or those people don't have enough money.

author: afdudley
content: if they are funds or whatever, they are fucking up ðŸ˜„

author: sky.cactus
content: They have money, they don't have connections.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is why marketing and offering services publicly is valuable.  Not everyone "knows a guy who knows a guy".

author: afdudley
content: it's... trivial. Literally just find a miner at a conference, ask them, and they will put you in contact with a sales person.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> just find a miner at a conference
Not everyone spends their time at conferences.

author: sky.cactus
content: The people I know spend their time writing bots at home.

author: afdudley
content: I mean, it just sounds like they aren't serious to me...

author: afdudley
content: if they are making millions of dollars a year on bots, they can get on a plane and meet a pool operator.

author: sky.cactus
content: Perhaps I'm underestimating what miners charge to put software into their infrastructure.

author: sky.cactus
content: If the cost is on the order of hundreds of thousands of dollars, then I think you are right that there are relatively few players at that scale.

author: afdudley
content: Just cornering PGAs probably won't make enough money to have a relationship with a mining pool.

author: sky.cactus
content: PGA?

author: afdudley
content: Price-Gas Auction

author: sky.cactus
content:
<@574864862338088960> This code is correct for the current set of parameters (and I think it even matches the EIP!) but I now realize that it isn't correct if block elasticity is anything other than 2x.
```java
    long baseFee =
        parentBaseFee
            + floorDiv(
                floorDiv(parentBaseFee * delta, targetGasUsed),
                feeMarket.getBasefeeMaxChangeDenominator());
```

author: sky.cactus
content: I wonder if we should bother adjusting the EIP to work with elasticity of something other than 2x, or if we should just leave it as it is until such time as we decide we want to fiddle with elasticity?

author: afdudley
content: Leave it, we are trying to launch a testnet.

author: abdel.stark
content: <@!301186049323958275> Yeah nice catch. We can address that later if we want to change the block elasticity.

author: abdel.stark
content: I created a test vectors file for base fee computation. Each test case define `parentBaseFee`, `parentGasUsed`, `targetGasUsed` and the `expectedBaseFee`. We could use it to compare results from different implementation. Obviously my implementation might be wrong. https://github.com/hyperledger/besu/blob/94b4ea126dce71585d91a297f61c658c24eaa541/ethereum/core/src/test/resources/org/hyperledger/besu/ethereum/core/fees/basefee-test.json

author: sky.cactus
content: As mentioned earlier, the formula is currently wrong for elasticity over (or under) 2x, so some of those tests cases are wrong by nature of the formula currently doesn't support them.

author: sky.cactus
content: If the `parentTargetGas` is 10, then the `parentGasUsed` cannot be more than 20.

author: sky.cactus
content: Nitpick: Rename `targetGasUsed` to `parentTargetGas` or `parentTargetGasUsed` for clarity.  ðŸ™‚

author: abdel.stark
content: <@!301186049323958275> What would be the generic formula ? I can update it to the generic formula and we can update the EIP

author: abdel.stark
content:
> Nitpick: Rename `targetGasUsed` to `parentTargetGas` or `parentTargetGasUsed` for clarity.  ðŸ™‚
<@!301186049323958275> Ok i will rename it

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, you know what, my nitpick was wrong, you shouldn't listen to me!

author: sky.cactus
content: `targetGas` is not per block, it is a fixed value.

author: abdel.stark
content:
`if CURRENT_BLKNUM >= FINAL_FORK_BLOKNUM then
  BLOCK_GAS_TARGET
elif CURRNT_BLKNUM < INITIAL_FORK_BLKNUM then
  0
else
  EIP1559_INITIAL_GAS_TARGET + LEGACY_INITIAL_GAS_LIMIT * (CURRENT_BLKNUM - INITIAL_FORK_BLKNUM) / MIGRATION_DURATION_IN_BLOCKS`

author: sky.cactus
content: `targetGasUsed` *is* a good name for it.  You should have challenged me.  ðŸ˜›

author: abdel.stark
content: I should have indeed

author: abdel.stark
content: We talk about BLOCK_GAS_TARGET in the spec right ?

author: sky.cactus
content: Actually, I suppose during transition it *is* variable per block?

author: abdel.stark
content: yeah

author: sky.cactus
content: So maybe I was right about my nitpick.  ðŸ˜›

author: abdel.stark
content: ok good, i already renamed and push

author: abdel.stark
content: So if you think we should use a more generic formula for block elasticity i am fine with that since i have to wait for Geth implementation before deploying a testnet anyway

author: sky.cactus
sky.cactus
content: *Definitely* double check the work to see if it seems reasonable/makes sense.

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, I may have that inverted actually...

author: abdel.stark
content: When you say changeable you mean by configuration or something like that?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.

author: sky.cactus
content: Like different chains may have different elasticity.

author: abdel.stark
content: Hmm ok

author: abdel.stark
content: I will add a CLI flag then

author: sky.cactus
content: Well, <@332923501079953409> thinks we shouldn't bother with it at this point.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: And he is the EIP owner so has more say than me on the subject!  I'm just an advocate.

author: afdudley
content: I mean, let's get a testnet up... it's a good idea, but we should be as close to feature freeze as possible at this point.

author: abdel.stark
content: Ok, let's keep as it is right now

author: sky.cactus
content: FWIW, this would be a backward compatible change that no one would need to actually implement unless we actually want to use different block elasticities for different chains.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, if you make this change you should get the exact same result out of your functions as someone who doesn't have this code, as long as you are using block elasticity of 2 for your testing.

author: sky.cactus
content: What we want is a linear function `f(gas_used_over_target) = fee_change_divisor` such that when `gas_used_over_target == 0` then `fee_change_divisor == 0` and when `gas_used_over_target == gasTarget * (elasticity - 1)` then `fee_change_divisor == 8`.

author: afdudley
content: sure, but as humans we only have so much time on this earth and if we are launching a testnet in a couple of days... let's not spend time on side quests ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: I am fine with not changing the spec for this, though I do think it would be a *minor* improvement as it would let us test with high elasticity on testnets, which could yield valuable information during testing.

author: afdudley
content: we'll just launch a different testnet.

author: afdudley
content: which would have its own sprint, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: I won't press this issue, I have many other hills I am currently dying on that are more important to me (by a long shot).  ðŸ˜„

author: abdel.stark
content: We need a script to fill blocks on the future EIP-1559 testnet with a mix of legacy and EIP-1559 transactions. I will write a tool to do that. I did the updates in web3j to be able to send EIP-1559 transactions including gas premium and fee cap fields.

author: abdel.stark
content: Description of the need: https://github.com/hyperledger/besu/issues/1167

author: sky.cactus
content: <@574864862338088960> Did you create a new JSON-RPC endpoint or just add optional fields to the transaction object in `eth_sendTransaction`, or are you using `eth_sendRawTransaction`?

author: abdel.stark
content: I am using eth_sendRawTransaction

author: hasu0730
content: Can someone explain to me the benefit of Barnabe Monnot's escalator on the basefee+tip over the regular escalator?

author: hasu0730
content: whether fixed or floating doesn't matter, but the general concept

author: hasu0730
content: Didn't know which barnabe to tag ðŸ˜„

author: barnabemonnot
content: right, it came up in the first or second implementers call, the question was raised "can we somehow combine the benefits of 1559 (the basefee that maps the current demand to some threshold price) and escalator (expressing time preferences)?"

author: barnabemonnot
content: it was more an intuition that you could somehow combine both, so i wanted to check how that could work, not really whether it was a good idea or not

author: barnabemonnot
content: but intuitively, the idea is that in a world where people respect the basefee + some fixed tip intuition, having an escalator option could allow you to "take off" above the crowd faster than other users' bid

author: barnabemonnot
content: hence you could express this time preference

author: barnabemonnot
content: but i am concerned that it's almost too expressive, and in a way it could "crowd out" 1559. i was hoping simulations might give an answer here

author: sky.cactus
content: <@486501030046203915> What do you mean "crowd out" 1559?

author: hasu0730
content: I'm not sure what I think about it tbh. I don't like losing the "fixed-price sale" benefit of 1559 / 1559 + tip escalator

author: hasu0730
content:
"can we somehow combine the benefits of 1559 (the basefee that maps the current demand to some threshold price) and escalator (expressing time preferences)?"

good to know, I wasn't aware what the motivation / design goal was until now

author: hasu0730
content: in that case, isn't the obvious combination 1559 + escalator for the tip?

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> <@!486501030046203915> What do you mean "crowd out" 1559?
<@!301186049323958275> yes that's unclear. i guess i mean put more emphasis on the tip auction rather than on the current price floor basefee operates. but this needs more thinking about

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> in that case, isn't the obvious combination 1559 + escalator for the tip?
<@!528251935829262351> this is what the floating escalator is. but i wanted to show other designs (even not very good ones) because it wasn't obvious, nor written down precisely before

author: hasu0730
content: really? we read it as an escalator on both basefee + the tip

author: hasu0730
content: meaning that you no longer specify feecap + tip, only start_bid, slope, and max_fee.

author: sky.cactus
content: That isn't how I would do it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would do escalator on tip only.

author: hasu0730
content: Same, I'm describing how I read Barnabe's description of floating escalator https://github.com/ethereum/rig/blob/master/eip1559/combination.md

author: sky.cactus
content:
> i guess i mean put more emphasis on the tip auction rather than on the current price floor basefee operates
<@486501030046203915> Hmm, I'm still not following.  The tip will only come into play when front-running (where you care about in-block ordering) and when there is a transient spike in usage.

author: sky.cactus
content: For the rest of the time, escalator is basically doing nothing.

author: hasu0730
content: it doesn't effect frontrunning either imo

author: hasu0730
content: current escalator does not bid intra-block. people have separate software for that

author: sky.cactus
content: I mean tip in general only comes into play in those situations.

author: sky.cactus
content: For the rest of the time, tip should be stable/flat.

author: hasu0730
content: Oh, misread. In that case I agree

author: sky.cactus
content: The hope is that for most people tip is just a "thing that gets set" rather than a "choice one has to make".

author: sky.cactus
content: If different miners demand different tips (certainly possible) you may have to choose a "speed".

author: hasu0730
content: People who care about intrablock ordering play their own little game with the tip that does not affect regular users, since there is always excess capacity in 1559

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., 50% of miners demand 1 nanoeth, 50% demand 2 nanoeth, if you want in next block you offer 2, if you don't mind waiting for a block or two then you offer 1.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> Same, I'm describing how I read Barnabe's description of floating escalator https://github.com/ethereum/rig/blob/master/eip1559/combination.md
<@!528251935829262351> this is why i wanted to be precise. but i get the sense your 1559 + escalator for the tip is what i called the floating escalator

author: barnabemonnot
content: in plain vanilla 1559, at time t, your bid is the basefee at t + the fixed premium you decided. in the floating escalator your bid is the basefee at t + where your premium is on the escalator at time t

author: hasu0730
content: your escalator does not change a user's bid for the basefee? (represented in 1559 by feecap minus tip)

author: barnabemonnot
content: no it doesn't

author: sky.cactus
content: Not in floating escalator.

author: barnabemonnot
content: maybe i can take an example

author: hasu0730
content: but the first two algorithms do?

author: sky.cactus
content: Barnabe describes several ways escalator could be applied, not all of them are good ideas.  :)

author: hasu0730
content: In that case I did not notice the paradigm shift between proposals 1+2 and 3 (floating escalator) while studying them

author: sky.cactus
content: (I appreciate you describing them all by the way <@486501030046203915>, makes discussion easier)

author: barnabemonnot
content: let's say basefee is 1 at t = 0. you set an escalator to increase your premium by 1 each block, and a start premium of 1. at t = 0 your bid is 2. Now say at t = 1 the basefee is 2. your bid is now 4 (the basefee is 2, + 1 start premium, + 1 from the escalation increment)

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> (I appreciate you describing them all by the way <@!486501030046203915>, makes discussion easier)
<@!301186049323958275> thanks but somehow i made it less clear ðŸ˜†

author: hasu0730
content: assuming we set feecap >= 4

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> assuming we set feecap >= 4
<@!528251935829262351> indeed! whatever happens, you never break the feecap

author: hasu0730
content: ok, then we are on the same page wrt the floating escalator

author: hasu0730
content: where does the floating part come in?

author: barnabemonnot
content: and yes, the fixed escalator is one where you only use basefee as your startbid, but then you escalate independently of basefee

author: barnabemonnot
content: from a discussion higher above where i likened basefee as a kind of tide... the floating escalator is on a boat: if the tide rises, you rise too because of it and also because you are on an escalator. the fixed escalator starts at the current level of the tide, but then rises only from the escalation, not with the tide

author: hasu0730
content: because it also "escalates" basefee?

author: afdudley
content: Heh, I have too much going on to follow all this, but any escalator should only be on the tip, and the other well discussed mechanisms adjust the basefee.

author: hasu0730
content: Yes, I think we all agree on that

author: barnabemonnot
content: yes it's a good summary. to end this let me just say the fixed escalator is just "regular escalator + a good default value for the starting bid (given by basefee)". floating escalator is the basefee + escalating tip intuition. and definitely i like the floating one better

author: hasu0730
content: This is the clean explanation of fixed escalator I've been hunting for, ty

author: sky.cactus
content: Someone should make a little animation of an elevator on a boat on the ocean.

author: sky.cactus
content: Well, several elevators, all racing each other on the boat.

author: sky.cactus
content: While the whole boat moves up and down with ocean waves.

author: hasu0730
content: pls dont ðŸ˜„ but the image of basefee as a wave works well. either that, or of an object flying into the air. in either case, gravity must pull it back down again

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> <@!486501030046203915> Hmm, I'm still not following.  The tip will only come into play when front-running (where you care about in-block ordering) and when there is a transient spike in usage.
<@!301186049323958275> as for this i don't disagree. it seemed to me that the current 1559 meme is everybody bids the same premium, and are distinguished either from maxing out their feecap or randomly if ties. you can still of course bid extra with your tip and jump ahead, deviating from the fixed tip meme, but with the escalator infrastructure, you can do that even _more_, since it's basically institutionalised by the protocol

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> Someone should make a little animation of an elevator on a boat on the ocean.
<@!301186049323958275> i would love that (sorry <@!528251935829262351> )

author: hasu0730
content: the 1559 "meme" if you will is that 95% of the time the premium doesn't matter, if we don't all bid the same

author: hasu0730
content: it's only via natural market forces that fees will equilibriate slightly above the cost of production for miners (which is the minimum they'll accept)

author: hasu0730
content:
> Assuming miners will continue to cap the block gas at 10M and demand continues to exceed the available block space would the whole eip 1559 system not just simply become again a first price auction for the tip + the additional basefee tax?
<@!471975503859810316> do people feel this question has been sufficiently addressed? it's hard to stay up to date with the debate

author: fatimaflash
content: Sorry for my ignorance, I am reading an article about this change

author: fatimaflash
content: "The proposal in this EIP is to start with a base fee amount which is adjusted up and down by the protocol based on how congested the network is. To accommodate this system, the total network capacity would be increased to 16 million gas. When the network exceeds the target 10 million gas usage, the base fee increments up slightly and when capacity is below the target, it decrements down slightly."

author: fatimaflash
content: Does this means that block size also becomes variable?

author: fatimaflash
content: I mean, it will hold more transactions, or less transactions?

author: fatimaflash
content: Or just the gas increases/decreases?

author: hasu0730
content: people told me they found this introduction helpful https://insights.deribit.com/market-research/analysis-of-eip-1559/

author: hasu0730
content: the short answer is yes, it introduces an elastic blocksize
